title: 114_hr3462
content: The Act may be cited as the "Sport Fish Restoration and Recreational Boating Safety Act of 2015". It includes allocations for various purposes. The Dingell-Johnson Sport Fish Restoration Act is amended to increase the percentage of authorization to 58.012 percent. Additionally, amendments are made to subsection (a) of Section 4, including changes to the allocation percentage to 18.673 percent for activities under section 14(e). The Dingell-Johnson Sport Fish Restoration Act is amended to increase the authorization percentage to 58.012 percent. Changes include adjusting allocation percentages, such as 18.673 percent for activities under section 14(e) and 4 percent to the Secretary of the Interior for boating infrastructure improvement projects. The Dingell-Johnson Sport Fish Restoration Act is amended to increase the authorization percentage to 58.012 percent. Changes include adjusting allocation percentages for projects under different sections. In subsection (b), adjustments are made for fiscal years through 2020, with specific funding amounts allocated. The Dingell-Johnson Sport Fish Restoration Act is amended to increase the authorization percentage to 58.012 percent. Funding amounts are adjusted for fiscal years 2018 through 2020, with specific allocations for each year. The Secretary of the department operating the Coast Guard can use specified amounts for fiscal years 2016-2020 for designated purposes under title 46, United States Code. The amounts are $7.8 million for 2016, $7.9 million for 2017, and $8 million for 2018. For fiscal years 2018, 2019, and 2020, the designated amounts are $8,000,000, $8,100,000, and $8,200,000 respectively. Amendments are made to paragraphs regarding the use of funds by the Secretary of the department operating the Coast Guard. Amendments are made to various sections of the Dingell-Johnson Sport Fish Restoration Act, including changes to the apportionment of funds, submission and approval of plans and projects, and handling of unexpended or unobligated funds. Amendments to the Dingell-Johnson Sport Fish Restoration Act include changing the apportionment of funds and other activities related to annual appropriations and available amounts. Amendments to the Dingell-Johnson Sport Fish Restoration Act involve reallocating funds and repealing certain sections. SEC. 3. RECREATIONAL BOATING SAFETY. Section 13107 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to allow the Secretary to use funds from the Dingell-Johnson Sport Fish Restoration Act for expenses related to recreational boating safety. The Secretary can use funds from the Dingell-Johnson Sport Fish Restoration Act for expenses related to administering State recreational boating safety programs and conducting national recreational boating safety activities. At least $2,500,000 must be used for compliance with chapter 43, and up to $1,500,000 for a survey of recreational boating participation in the United States. "On and after October 1, 2015, no funds traditionally allocated for compliance with chapter 43 will be used." SEC. 4. ANNUAL ASSESSMENT. The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service must provide Congress with an assessment of administrative services under the Dingell-Johnson Sport Fish Restoration Act. The assessment includes grant processing times and updates on wildlife and sport fish restoration policies. The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service must report to Congress on various aspects including the number of workshops held with States, response time to State assistance requests, unresolved land record reconciliations, employee training, and State staff training through the Wildlife and Sport Fish Restoration Fund Program. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service must report to Congress on the number of positions contributing to grant processing and management in each region and headquarters of the Wildlife and Sport Fish Restoration Fund Program.
